Comments_List: Greatly enhanced my understanding of research designs -- usual critiques of them (not accounting for selection effects, not acknowledging measurement error and likely bias direction, etc.) and types of good ones (regression discontinuities, in appropriate context, within-unit change pre-/post-treatment). Papers were a chance to explore some ideas to potentially use in research one day.

I significantly improved my familiarity with the core American Politics literature. This class also strengthened my ability to critique scholarship while motivating my own research questions for future inquiry.

The course is great! Got to learn a ton about the various ways Americanists go about research. Really think I developed my capacity to critique in this course. More so than in any academic environment I've been in, I think, I really felt like we all had smart feedback on the papers/books we discussed.
I gained a comprehensive understanding of many foundational aspects of American political science. I became a much better critical reader because of the depth required for a good reading response.

Combo of Greg's bit of lecture with mostly discussion seemed quite effective. Not too much reading, though sometimes a serious amount (but never too much). I like the 5-paper model (and not having a final is pretty nice...).
The structure of the course was excellent. I recommend mostly keeping it as it is.
Hard to come up with any weaknesses. Greg did a phenomenal job!
More direction for student discussion leading.
Absolutely. Really challenges students to think through research designs.
Absolutely. Greg Huber's expertise in American politics is exceptional. It was an honor to be able to critically analyze academic work with him and the other students.
